section.name: PRINCIPLES AND PRACTICE OF QUALITY IMPROVEMENT AND SAFETY I

comments:
The goal of this interprofessional course is to provide students with a broad
overview of the principles and tools of quality improvement and patient safety in
healthcare as well address the knowledge, skills and attitudes as defined by the Quality
and Safety Education for Nurses (QSEN) guidelines. It provides a foundation for
students or practicing clinicians who are interested in quality improvement and patient
safety research, administration, or clinical applications. Content addresses the history of
the quality improvement process in healthcare, quality databases and improvement
process tools and programs. Through the use of case studies and exercises students
become familiar with the use of several quality improvement programs and tools. For
example, the Plan-Do-Study- Act (PDSA) cycle, Six Sigma and the Toyota Production
System known as Lean Production processes are addressed. Students can use this course
to identify the tools and design the methods that they plan to employ in a quality
improvement or patient safety project in their area of interest.
Overall, students felt that this course was “a good introduction” and “very
interesting” and “interactive.” Furthermore, several students praised the course for being
“very practical,” while others felt it could have “a bit more emphasis on theory.” Other
students praised the variety of students and perspectives presented in the course.
Students praised Burke’s lectures, but they felt there was “too much busy work”
and that the “project was very time-consuming.”
Overall, students “would recommend this course to others in the healthcare,” but
some “did not feel that the material was at the level of a Master's course at Penn.” Also,
other students felt that the information was unevenly distributed claiming that, “some of
the curriculum overlapped too much and other important areas were only surveyed.”

section.name: PRINCIPLES AND PRACTICE OF QUALITY IMPROVEMENT AND SAFETY I

comments:
This course includes the major topics of cell biology and microbiology that are
foundational for an understanding of normal and pathological cellular processes. Topics
include the study of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell structures and functions, the main
biological molecules, membrane transport, cellular communications, the flow of genetic
information, cell division, and cellular metabolism. The context for this course is the
application of cell biology to understanding the cellular basis of human diseases and the
role of genetics and genomics in health and disease processes.
The course provides "a very good foundation" to quality improvement in
healthcare. Students found the material diverse, interesting, and organized. Moreover,
students remarked that the course would have practical and professional applications for
them.
The course is co-taught by Professors Myers and Burke. Students liked having
projects instead of tests, but felt that professor-student communication could have been
better. Students benefited from the diverse perspectives offered by guest speakers.
Students did not find the course too difficult, but several remarked on the amount
of "busywork" and rushed project completion timeframe. This course is highly relevant
for students planning to enter healthcare professions.
